title: Virgin script
content:
I believe this is a custom job, but is anyone aware of something manufactured that “emulates” this typeface?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200325im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/-1_4587.png)

 [‹ (x) Indiana Jones and The Last Crusade movie logo - SF Fedora {Jan E}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200325/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36240 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) similar to Akzidenz Grotesk Condensed - H&FJ Knockout No. 90 {Eric Gordon, Yves} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200325/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36206 "Go to next forum topic")
author: anotheruser

comments.content: [Freehand 575](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200325/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/bitstream/freehand_575_regular_ot/?sample_text=Virgin&sample_size=144) has roots in 40s-50s advertising lettering, but it can look more contemporary with some adjustments.

I was looking for something with less of a loop on the ’g’ and came up with Letraset [Rapier](http://web.archive.org/). (see attached) Remove the connecting lines and it’s not too far off, I think.

- Mike Yanega

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200325im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/RapierVirgin_4689.gif)

[Freestyle Script Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202200325/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/itc/freestyle_script_bold/?sample_text=Virgin&sample_size=36) has the bold monoline feel of your sample. You’d have to remove the connecting lines on this one as well.

- Lex
